writing_prompt: Years after their childhood hero, the shortstop, was traded away, two old friends reunite and unexpectedly find themselves reliving the rituals of their youth, grappling with what was lost and what still remains.
story:
The sky was a patchwork of soft grays, the kind of overcast that seemed to hold the world in a gentle embrace. Tom adjusted his glasses and squinted at the address on his phone, verifying the house number once more before stepping up to the front door. He hadn’t seen Jake in nearly a decade, not since the reunion that had brought a few of the old gang back together in a fit of nostalgia. But here they were, two middle-aged men, about to reconnect over a shared past that seemed both close and impossibly distant.

Jake opened the door with a broad smile that almost hid the lines etched deep into his face. “Tommy, you old dog! Get in here!” His voice was gruffer than Tom remembered, but the warmth was unmistakable. They embraced awkwardly, a mix of claps on the back and half-laughs, both men conscious of the weight of the years between them.

The house was modest but cozy, filled with the smell of fresh coffee and something sweet baking in the oven. Tom noticed the framed photographs lining the hallway—snapshots of Jake’s family, vacations, milestones. But one picture caught his eye: a black-and-white photograph of a young baseball player, mid-dive, glove outstretched. It was their hero, Richie “The Flash” Thompson, the shortstop who had once seemed larger than life.

“Still got that, huh?” Tom nodded toward the photo.

“Of course,” Jake said, handing Tom a steaming mug. “You don’t just forget your heroes, right?”

They settled into the living room, the conversation flowing with the ease of old friends falling back into familiar rhythms. They talked about work, family, and the inexorable march of time. But the undercurrent of their shared past tugged at them, pulling them back to a simpler time.

“Remember when we used to sneak onto the high school field at night?” Jake asked, his eyes twinkling with mischief.

Tom laughed, the memory vivid. “Yeah, and we’d pretend we were playing under the lights of Fenway Park, just like Richie.”

The hours melted away as they talked, each story sparking another. They decided to take a walk to their old haunt, the now-abandoned baseball field that had once been their kingdom. The grass was overgrown, the dugouts dilapidated, but the ghosts of their past games lingered in the air.

Jake jogged ahead to the pitcher’s mound, the same boyish enthusiasm lighting up his face. “Think you can still throw a curveball, old man?”

Tom picked up a rock and mimed a pitch, feeling the years slip away. “You bet I can.”

They found a couple of sticks to use as bats and an old tennis ball lying in the weeds. It wasn’t much, but it was enough. They took turns pitching and hitting, their laughter echoing across the empty field. It felt good, like slipping into a favorite old jacket that still fit just right.

As the sun dipped below the horizon, they sat on the bleachers, breathing heavily but grinning like fools. Tom looked at Jake, the setting sun casting long shadows across his face, and felt a pang of something deep and bittersweet.

“Do you ever think about what we lost?” Tom asked quietly.

Jake was silent for a moment, then nodded. “Yeah, I do. When Richie got traded, it felt like the end of something, you know? Like we lost more than just a player.”

Tom knew exactly what he meant. Richie had been more than a hero; he had been a symbol of their youth, their dreams, and their unshakeable bond. When he was traded away, it was as if a part of their childhood had been ripped away too.

“But look at us,” Jake said, a smile creeping back onto his face. “We’re still here, still friends. Maybe we didn’t lose as much as we thought.”

Tom smiled, feeling a warmth spread through him. “Yeah, maybe you’re right.”

They sat in companionable silence, the air thick with the scent of grass and earth, the sounds of the night creeping in around them. Tom thought about all the years that had passed, all the changes they had both endured. But here, in this moment, it felt like some part of their youth still lived on.

“You know,” Jake said, breaking the silence, “I’ve got Richie’s rookie card somewhere in the attic. Wanna go find it?”

Tom’s eyes lit up. “Absolutely.”

Back at Jake’s house, they rummaged through boxes of old memorabilia, laughing at the ridiculousness of some of their childhood treasures. Finally, Jake pulled out a worn shoebox and opened it to reveal the card. Richie’s face beamed up at them, eternally young and full of promise.

They sat on the floor, the card between them, and toasted their past with a couple of cold beers from Jake’s fridge. They talked late into the night, revisiting old memories and making new ones, the bond between them as strong as ever.

As Tom drove home the next morning, he felt a sense of peace. They might have lost their childhood hero, but they had found something far more enduring: the friendship that had carried them through, the rituals that still held meaning, and the memories that would always be a part of them. And in that, there was something timeless, something that would never fade away.
